comments: Sybase is contributing the graphical page designer to the project. Will use this entry for the source code contribution.

Created an attachment (id=47287)
source code contribution of web pagedesigner

Initial web page designer source code contribution to JST/JSF project by Sybase.

Cool, thanks Jean!

Just for anyone else who wants to try it the following dependencies worked for me:

Eclipse 3.2
WTP 1.5 (Callisto) including its dependencies: GEF, EMF, JEM
JSF 0.5 (Callisto)

The plugins here can then be imported to the workspace as source and run as a child workbench.

Issue: Undo's are not congruent with actions

I came across a case where I dragged a command button on the canvas from one position to another.  This worked well, but I had to hit undo twice to restore the canvas state to where it was before the drag.  The command to move the button seems to be split into two commands: one to delete the button at its current position and one to add at the drop position.  This makes sense from an design point of view, but not from a user point of view.  The two commands need to be chained into one undoable parent command.
This is a bug.  It didn't happen in our original source code, this could be caused by the refactoring of the code.

Encountered the following stack trace while playing with the VE.  The problem seems to occur because the page designer does not ensure that resource changed events are run on the UI thread.  The NPE appears to occur when Display.getCurrent() returns null (indicating there is no current display, usually indicating not on a UI thread):

Issue: Tooltip should be turned off during drag.

When dragging a widget, if you stop moving the mouse then the tooltip will activate and not go away.  This can obscure the drop location completely and makes dnd much less usable, especially for widgets that have large tooltip descriptions.

Created an attachment (id=47804)
Design document of visual page designer

Nice contribution! This is a great first step toward finally having a WYSIWYG web page editor for WTP. I'd assume most of this code should live in WST and only the  JSP specifc bits should go into WST.
Yes, the plan is for most of the code to be in WST and the JSF specific code will live in the JSF sub-project.
If I could vote for this bug, I'd give it a +1!  Thanks.

(In reply to comment #11)
> If I could vote for this bug, I'd give it a +1!  Thanks.
> 

Hi Dave,

Have you had a chance to look at the contribution?  I'm looking at your site for the XSWT tool and it seems to me that we have a similar goal in terms of a visual designer for JSF as you have for SWT apps. Both editors appear to be based on a component model encoded in XML.  Do you see any possible synergies?

The JSF portion has compilation errors under WTP 1.5.1/Eclipse 3.2.1 ..perhaps I didn't import them correctly. For those of us who are not plugin developers, could someone provide instructions on how to import and run these?
There are some instructions at the top of the bug.  Have you installed the JSF tooling in addition to WTP and its dependencies?
I saw the instructions - a few more lines would be nice if you want end users like myself to give it a shot. I don't have JSF installed so, yes, that would be a reason why JSF portion didn't compile.

Created an attachment (id=52153)
Clean up copyright issues

Source code contribution of web pagedesigner, clean up some copyright issues raised by code review.

Jean:
This is freaking awwwwwesome.
A tad slow in runtime hosting mode, yet so cool.

I already have a patch to contribute.
The palette does not displays (and there is an NPE) if the project you are opening an HTML from is not a Java project.
What form or shape could I submit that to you?
The fix is very simple:
in bundle org.eclipse.jst.pagedesigner in org.eclipse.jst.pagedesigner.editors.palette.impl.PaletteItemManager
method: registerTldFromClasspath(IProject)
add that line of code marked with a +:

private void registerTldFromClasspath(IProject project) {
  J2EEFlexProjDeployable jdeploy = new J2EEFlexProjDeployable(project);
+ if (jdeploy == null) return;
  IPath[] paths = jdeploy.getClasspath();
  for (int i = 0; i < paths.length; i++) {

This takes care of the NPE when the jdeploy varibale is null.


I think that generally having a clean split between HTML, vs JSP vs JSF is also desirable, as it could be an excellent html only editor too.


Finally, do you have unit tests for it?
If so, would you contribute them too?
That would be cool.

I have seen that your manifests do both an export and provide pacakge. Just curious why?
And also why do you often re-export the visibility of the required bundles?
And aslo org.eclipse.jst.pagedesigner.jsp.core repackages the servlet Api.
Why not instaed relying on the org.eclipse.equinox.servlet.api bundle?
Note that org.eclipse.jst.pagedesigner.common/build.properties is missing a plugin.properties properties entry

Phillip,

I believe the cause of the palette doesn't display in the palette view is because we didn't include the html_basic.tld and jsf_core.tld files in the org.eclipse.jst.pagedesigner\jsf-tld folder.  Because those 2 files have the Sun's copyright.  If you can add those 2 files, that should solve the problem.  The HTML and JSP editor is already in separate plugins. Actually, the basic editor is HTML and JSP editor, JSF editor is an extension. 

We have some unittest, but have not cleanup to the point of the contribution yet.

Created an attachment (id=52358)
Patch to fix an NPE when displaying the palette and the project that contains the html page is not a java or web tools project.s

(In reply to comment #21)
(In reply to comment #19)
Folks, I must have been drunk when I typed that.
Yet I am correct to say that the palette goes into NPE when the project is not a Java project or a web tools project.
And it has nothing to do with tld being present or not, and the bug exist also on your first drop, Jean, that has the tld's in.
The fix is attached in the attached patch.

Note that I have the patched code in my public CVS at:
http://easyeclipse.cvs.sourceforge.net/easyeclipse/easyeclipse/easyedit/plugins/
HEAD contains Jean's latest version.
WYSIWYG_EDITOR_PATCHES is a branch that contains that patch plus various minor fixes and updates.

Thanks for your interest in the contribution. We are very close to passing the IP review on the contribution and we will checkin the code in the CVS. You can then submit patches on the code.

Also, please let us know if you would like to participate in the development of this feature for the WTP 2.0 release. We have posted the features that we are planning in the Visual Page Designer here: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Visual_JSF_Page_Designer

Please review and give your feedback.
We already got IP review clearance from eclipse.org. The new attachment already fixed all the IP review issues.

The code contribution has been fully integrated into the 2.0 build stream targeting 2.0M4 as the first release build.  The other issues noted in this bug have been split off as follows:

163878: [pagedesigner] Undo's are not congruent with actions
163879: [pagedesigner] Workspace listener not synching with UI th...
163880: [pagedesigner] Usability problem with tooltip on canvas drag
166159:  [design request] JSF tooling should work without facets (includes patch 52358).
Main issue closed.  Other issues still open per above.
